[See Results](https://www.polleverywhere.com/multiple_choice_polls/qKeig0hHShZYHAOmvZtZm?preview=true&controls=none){preview-link="true"} ::: :::: # Uncertainty and Probability ## What Is Probability? ::: {.fragment .fade-in} How we communicate/capture uncertainty depends on how we interpret probability: 1. **Frequentist**: $\mathbb{P}[A]$ is the long-run *frequency* of event A occurring. 2. **Bayesian**: $\mathbb{P}[A]$ is the degree of belief (betting odds) of event A occurring. ::: ## Frequentist Probability - Data is random, but there is a "true" parameter set for a given model. - Concerned with consistency of estimates of those parameters obtained from different samples. ## Bayesian Probability Two different types of random quantities: 1. Observable quantities, or data (also random for frequentists); 2. Unobservable quantities, or parameters (not random for frequentists!). ## Bayesian Probability Can discuss the *probability* of - model parameters $\mathbf{\theta}$ - unobserved data $\tilde{\mathbf{y}}$ conditional on the observations $\mathbf{y}$, which we can denote: $$p(\mathbf{\theta} | \mathbf{y}) \text{ or } p(\tilde{\mathbf{y}} | \mathbf{y})$$ ## Bayes' Rule Original version [@Bayes1763-at]: $$P(A | B) = \frac{P(B | A) \times P(A)}{P(B)} \quad \text{if} \quad P(B) \neq 0.$$ ## Bayes' Rule: Later generalized [@Laplace1774-nf]: $$\underbrace{{p(\theta | y)}}_{\text{posterior}} = \frac{\overbrace{p(y | \theta)}^{\text{likelihood}}}{\underbrace{p(y)}_\text{normalization}} \overbrace{p(\theta)}^\text{prior}$$ ## Confidence Intervals Frequentist estimates have **confidence intervals**: - If you repeat the experiment and re-do the analysis, how often are your estimates "wrong" due to outlying data? - The procedure for generating an $\alpha$% confidence interval will contain the "true" data-generating parameters for $\alpha$% of experiments. - **This says nothing about whether a given interval contains the "true" value!** ## Credible Intervals Bayesian estimates have **credible intervals**: - Every parameter has a distribution associated with it () ## Projection Intervals Simulations have **projection intervals** summarizing the sampling distribution of the simulated data. # References ## References
